Its not as trivial as 'int i = "foo"'.  I have a set of nested classes 
and interfaces with a somewhat complex inheritance/implementation 
structure.  They act of "connection" nodes.  The nodes are "typed" for 
In and Out, as well as for data, as in In<MyObject>.  I want to make 
sure that an In can only connect to an Out, that only certain methods 
can be called on an In and not an Out, and that a <MyObject> can only 
connect to a <? extends MyObject>.  This requires attempting to make a 
bad connection and then asserting that it results in a compile error. 
The neccessity for making such "compiler error" tests is real given that 
changes to extension, implementation, and method visibility affect what 
should and should not compile and therefore must be tested.  In other 
words, whether the problem is static or dynamic, testing is important.

Ideally, as with any testing, I'd like to be able to incorporate the 
"bad" tests right alongside the "good" tests, rather than sticking the 
bad ones off in some separate file that must be compiled separately. 
Note also that such an approach means that EACH "bad compile" test 
statement must be put into its own file and invoked with javac to see if 
the compile failed.

Also, I'd prefer a general solution as opposed to a specific one.  The 
issue of needing to make compile error (static) tests is a real one, and 
has been exacerbated with the introduction of 1.5 generics.

--jon

jason r tibbetts wrote:

> jonbarril wrote:
> 
>>Is there any way to "catch" a compile error for failure assertion?
>>
>>I have classes whose methods accept specific combinations of generic
>>parameter types, and I want to test to make sure that the bad
>>combinations truly generate compile errors.  I have not been able to
>>figure out an automatic way to test for a compile error as part of my
>>JUnit test suite.  Currently, I have to manually uncomment the bad
>>code lines to "test" if they are still bad compiles.  Is there a
>>better way?
> 
> 
> If I understand your scenario correctly, you're testing a feature of the 
> 1.5 language. That's like testing whether the statement 'int i = "foo"' 
> will compile. Why must that be tested?
> 
> That said, I suppose that you could rig up a test that calls 
> java.lang.Runtime.exec("javac " + filename) on a number of pre-existing 
> *.java files that will trigger the expected compilation error. You'd 
> have to examine the Process object that's returned by exec(), wait for 
> it to finish, then assert its exit value and/or error and output 
> streams. I wouldn't want to be the one who writes that test, though.
